subTopics.title: Constituent Assembly - Formation to Adoption
subTopics.description: Navigate through formation, Drafting Committee (Dr. Ambedkar), sessions, debates, and adoption of Constitution

keyTakeaways: Formed based on Cabinet Mission Plan (1946) - 389 members (299 after partition)
Dr. Rajendra Prasad = President; Dr. B.R. Ambedkar = Drafting Committee Chairman
Worked for 2 years, 11 months, 18 days (165 sittings)
Objectives Resolution (Nehru, Jan 1947) - Soul of Constitution
Drafting Committee had 7 members (Ambedkar, Ayyar, Ayyangar, Munshi, Saadulla, Mitter, Khaitan)
Constitution adopted Nov 26, 1949; enforced Jan 26, 1950
Borrowed from 15+ countries (mainly GOI Act 1935, UK, US, Ireland, Canada)
Open, democratic, consensus-based process

topics.description: Study the Preamble with special visual layout - actual Preamble text on left, comprehensive smart notes on right covering keywords, 42nd Amendment, socialism, secularism, and key cases

subTopics.title: Preamble - Keywords & Amendments

keyTakeaways: 5 key terms: SOVEREIGN, SOCIALIST, SECULAR, DEMOCRATIC, REPUBLIC
4 objectives: JUSTICE (social, economic, political), LIBERTY (thought, expression, belief, faith, worship), EQUALITY (status, opportunity), FRATERNITY (dignity, unity, integrity)
42nd Amendment 1976 added: SOCIALIST, SECULAR, INTEGRITY
Source: Objectives Resolution (Nehru, 1947)
Called 'Soul of Constitution' (T.T. Krishnamachari)
Amendable (Kesavananda Bharati 1973 overruled Berubari 1960)
Indian socialism = Democratic socialism (not communism); Indian secularism = Sarva Dharma Sambhava

keyTakeaways: Part III (Art 12-35) contains all Fundamental Rights
6 main categories: Equality, Freedom, Against Exploitation, Religion, Cultural-Educational, Constitutional Remedies
Art 14 (Equality) and Art 21 (Life & Liberty) most expansive and litigated
Art 19 originally had 7 freedoms; now 6 (property removed in 1978)
Art 32 (Constitutional Remedies) called 'heart and soul of Constitution' by Dr. Ambedkar
5 writs: Habeas Corpus (illegal detention), Mandamus (command duty), Prohibition (prevent before), Certiorari (quash after), Quo Warranto (public office)
Art 32 (SC) = FR itself, FRs only, All India; Art 226 (HC) = discretionary, FRs + other rights, State only
FRs not absolute - reasonable restrictions on Art 19 (Art 19(2)-(6))
Exceptions: Preventive detention (Art 22), Armed forces (Art 33), Martial Law (Art 34), Emergency (Art 358, 359), Saving laws (Art 31A/B/C), Immunity (Art 361)
44th Amendment: Art 20-21 cannot be suspended even during Emergency

keyTakeaways: Part IV (Art 36-51) contains Directive Principles - non-justiciable but fundamental in governance
7 categories: Foundation, Social Justice, Economic, Gandhian, Administrative, Environmental, International
Art 37 declares DPSPs non-justiciable (unlike FRs) but fundamental
Art 39 has 6 crucial clauses (a-f) - frequently asked
Art 44 (UCC) most debated - only Goa has implemented
Art 48A (Environment) and Art 43A (Worker participation) added by 42nd Amendment 1976
DPSPs complement FRs: FRs are means, DPSPs are ends

topics.description: Master the comparison between FRs and DPSPs (25+ points) and understand major conflicts, constitutional amendments, and landmark cases that shaped their relationship

subTopics.title: Fundamental Rights vs DPSPs - Complete Comparison

subTopics.title: Conflicts between FRs and DPSPs
subTopics.description: Navigate through major conflicts, landmark cases (Champakam, Kesavananda, Minerva Mills), constitutional amendments (Art 31C, 31A/B), property right battle, and modern harmonious construction approach

keyTakeaways: FRs: Justiciable, Negative, Individual-centric, Enforceable, Borrowed from USA; DPSPs: Non-justiciable, Positive, Society-centric, Non-enforceable, Borrowed from Ireland
Champakam (1951): FRs prevail over DPSPs; Led to 1st Amendment (Art 15(4))
Kesavananda (1973): Basic Structure - Balance between FRs and DPSPs is basic feature; Neither absolute supremacy
Minerva Mills (1980): 'Two lungs' theory - FRs and DPSPs both essential; Art 31C limited to Art 39(b), (c) only
Art 31C (25th Amendment 1971): Laws implementing Art 39(b), (c) protected from Art 14, 19 challenge
Art 31A, 31B (1st Amendment 1951): Protect land reforms; Ninth Schedule (284 Acts); I.R. Coelho (2007) limited immunity
Property right: Removed as FR (44th Amendment 1978) - biggest FR-DPSP conflict resolved
Modern approach: Harmonious construction; Courts expand Art 21 to include DPSP goals (livelihood, education, health, environment)
Granville Austin: 'FRs are means; DPSPs are ends' - Complementary not contradictory

topics.description: Complete coverage of constitutional amendment procedure (Art 368), three types of amendments, and landmark cases that shaped Parliament's amendment power

subTopics.title: Constitutional Amendments - Types, Procedure & Cases
subTopics.description: Navigate through types of amendments (Simple Majority, Special Majority, Special Majority + States), procedure, and landmark cases (Shankari Prasad, Golak Nath, Kesavananda, Minerva Mills, Waman Rao) with trends analysis

keyTakeaways: 106 Amendments till 2023; Art 368 provides procedure; Flexible yet rigid
Type 1: Simple Majority - Federal structure (Art 2-4), Citizenship (Art 5-11), Elections (Art 324-329)
Type 2: Special Majority - Most amendments (FRs, DPSPs); 2/3 present & voting + Majority of total strength
Type 3: Special Majority + 50% States - Federal provisions (President election, SC/HC, 7th Schedule, Art 368 itself)
Shankari Prasad (1951): Unlimited power to amend; Later overruled
Golak Nath (1967): FRs CANNOT be amended; Overruled Shankari & Sajjan; Led to 24th Amendment
Kesavananda (1973): Basic Structure doctrine - Can amend BUT not destroy basic structure; 13-judge bench, 7:6 verdict
Minerva Mills (1980): 'Two lungs' theory; Art 31C limited; Judicial review protected
42nd Amendment 1976: 'Mini Constitution' - Most controversial (Emergency period); Many provisions struck down
99th Amendment (NJAC) struck down by SC (2015) - Violated basic structure (judicial independence)

topics.description: Comprehensive coverage of India's federal structure - comparison with unitary system, federal features, and parliamentary vs presidential systems

subTopics.title: Federal vs Unitary System - Complete Comparison
subTopics.description: Comprehensive comparison table (20+ points) covering definition, power distribution, autonomy, amendment, suitability, advantages/disadvantages, with Indian context (Quasi-federal)

subTopics.title: Federal Features of Indian Constitution
subTopics.description: Navigate through 7 major federal features: Dual Polity (Art 1), Written Constitution, Division of Powers (7th Schedule), Constitutional Supremacy, Rigidity, Independent Judiciary, Bicameralism

subTopics.title: Parliamentary vs Presidential System
subTopics.description: Comprehensive comparison table (25+ points) covering executive structure, selection, responsibility, stability, checks and balances, with Indian parliamentary system details (Art 74, 75)

keyTakeaways: Art 1: India is 'Union of States' (NOT Federation - states cannot secede)
K.C. Wheare: India is 'Quasi-federal' - Federal in structure, Unitary in spirit

Federal features: Dual polity, Written Constitution, Division of powers (7th Schedule), Constitutional supremacy, Rigid (federal provisions need state consent), Independent judiciary (Art 131), Bicameralism (Rajya Sabha)

Unitary features: Strong Centre, Single citizenship, Integrated judiciary, Emergency (Art 352, 356, 360), Governor, All India Services, Centre can legislate on State List (emergency, national interest)
7th Schedule: Union List (97), State List (61), Concurrent (47); Residuary to Union (Art 248); Conflict: Union prevails (Art 254)
S.R. Bommai (1994): Federalism is basic structure; Cannot be destroyed
Parliamentary System (Art 74, 75): Dual executive (President nominal, PM real), Collective responsibility, PM from Parliament, No-confidence can remove, Fusion of powers
Presidential System (USA): Single executive (President), Direct election, Fixed term, Separation of powers, No collective responsibility
India chose Parliamentary: Familiarity (British rule), Accountability, Diverse country (Presidential risky), Dr. Ambedkar's reasoning
Parliamentary system is basic structure (S.R. Bommai) - Cannot be changed

subTopics.title: Centre-State Financial Relations
subTopics.description: Master taxation powers distribution, tax devolution (Art 270), Finance Commission (Art 280), grants-in-aid (Art 275, 282), borrowing (Art 293), and GST Council (Art 279A)

keyTakeaways: 7th Schedule: Union List (97) - Defence, Currency, Railways; State List (61) - Police, Agriculture, Land; Concurrent (47) - Criminal law, Education; Residuary â†’ Union (Art 248)
Parliament in State field: Art 249 (Rajya Sabha 2/3, national interest, 1 year), Art 250 (Emergency), Art 252 (State consent, permanent), Art 253 (International treaty)
Repugnancy (Art 254): Concurrent List conflict â†’ Union law prevails; Exception: President-assented state law (but Parliament can override)
Executive powers: Art 73 (Union - Union+Concurrent+Residuary), Art 162 (State - State+Concurrent, subject to Union)
Centre's directions: Art 256 (Comply with Union laws), Art 257 (Not impede Union - railways, communications)
President's Rule (Art 356): Constitutional machinery failure; Misused 125+ times; S.R. Bommai (1994) - Federalism is basic structure, floor test mandatory, justiciable
All India Services (Art 312): IAS, IPS, IFS - Dual control (Union recruits, States serve, Union controls); Shows Union's control over State administration
Taxation: Union (Income, Customs, Corporation, Inter-state GST), States (Land revenue, Agricultural income, Liquor excise, Intra-state GST); 101st Amendment (GST 2016)
Tax devolution (Art 270): 14th FC (42% to States), 15th FC (41%); Surcharges, cesses NOT shareable (controversy)
Finance Commission (Art 280): Constituted every 5 years; Recommends devolution, grants (Art 275); 14th FC (Y.V. Reddy), 15th FC (N.K. Singh)
Grants: Art 275 (Statutory - equalization), Art 282 (Discretionary - CSS like MGNREGA, PMAY); Tied grants erode federalism
GST Council (Art 279A - 101st Amendment): Union FM + States' FMs; Weighted majority (Union 1/3, States 2/3); Best example of cooperative federalism
Vertical imbalance: Union has more revenue, States have more expenditure â†’ States depend on devolution, grants, loans

topics.description: Comprehensive comparison of three types of emergencies (National, State, Financial) with constitutional provisions, historical instances, landmark cases, and safeguards

subTopics.title: Emergency Provisions - Part XVIII (Art 352-360)
subTopics.description: Side-by-side comparison of National Emergency (Art 352), State Emergency/President's Rule (Art 356), and Financial Emergency (Art 360) covering grounds, effects, duration, safeguards, and historical instances

keyTakeaways: Three types: National Emergency (Art 352), State Emergency/President's Rule (Art 356), Financial Emergency (Art 360)
National Emergency (Art 352): War, External aggression, Armed rebellion (44th Amendment changed 'internal disturbance'); Used 3 times (1962, 1971, 1975)
1975 Emergency: Most controversial; 21 months; Democracy suspended; Led to 44th Amendment safeguards
44th Amendment 1978: Special majority required, Cabinet advice in writing, Art 20-21 CANNOT be suspended, LS can disapprove
Art 358: If war/external aggression â†’ Art 19 automatically suspended; Art 359: President can suspend other FRs (except Art 20-21)
State Emergency (Art 356): Constitutional machinery failure; Used 125+ times (most misused); State govt dismissed, Parliament rules State
S.R. Bommai (1994): Federalism is basic structure; Art 356 justiciable; Floor test mandatory; Dramatically reduced misuse
President's Rule duration: 6 months initially; Max 3 years (44th Amendment); Extension beyond 1 year needs National Emergency OR EC certification
Financial Emergency (Art 360): Threat to financial stability; NEVER used (0 times); Union can control State finances, reduce salaries
Effects: National Emergency (Federal â†’ Unitary, Parliament on State List, FRs suspended); State Emergency (State govt dismissed, no FR effect); Financial Emergency (Financial control, no FR effect)

topics.description: Comprehensive coverage of Union Executive bodies - President, Vice President, Prime Minister, and Council of Ministers with tabbed interface + Quick Comparison tab for side-by-side analysis

subTopics.title: Union Executive - Part V (Art 52-78)
subTopics.description: Tab-based interface with ðŸ“Š Compare All tab showing all bodies side-by-side, plus individual tabs for President (Art 52-62), Vice President (Art 63-71), Prime Minister (Art 75), and Council of Ministers (Art 74-75) with constitutional provisions, election, powers, and removal procedures

keyTakeaways: Parliamentary system: Dual executive - President nominal (constitutional head), PM real (head of government)
President (Art 52-62): Elected by Electoral College (MPs+MLAs) via STV; 5-year term; Removable by impeachment (Art 61 - violation of Constitution, never used)
President acts on Cabinet advice (Art 74 - 44th Amendment); Very limited discretion after 44th Amendment

President's powers: Appoints PM/Ministers/Judges/CAG/EC/Governors, Part of Parliament, Pardoning (Art 72), Ordinance (Art 123 - 6 weeks), Veto (Absolute/Suspensive/Pocket), Emergency (Art 352/356/360)
Vice President (Art 63-71): Elected by MPs only (no MLAs) via STV; Ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha (Art 64); Acts as President when President unable (Art 65)
VP removable by RS resolution (absolute majority) agreed by LS; Not impeachment, simpler process; No executive powers as VP (only as Acting President)
Prime Minister (Art 75): Real executive head; Leader of majority in Lok Sabha; Appointed by President; Must be MP (within 6 months)
PM removable by no-confidence in LS (Art 75(3) - collective responsibility); Powers - Appoints Ministers, Allocates portfolios, Advises President, Chairs Cabinet, Dissolves LS
Council of Ministers (Art 74-75): Headed by PM; Aids and advises President; Types - Cabinet Ministers, MoS, Deputy Ministers; Max 15% of LS (91st Amendment 2003)
Collective responsibility (Art 75(3)): All Ministers collectively responsible to LS; No-confidence â†’ All resign together; Individual responsibility for own Ministry

topics.description: Comprehensive coverage of State Executive bodies - Governors, Chief Ministers, and State Council of Ministers with tabbed interface + Quick Comparison tab mirroring Union Executive structure

subTopics.title: State Executive - Part VI (Art 153-167)
subTopics.description: Tab-based interface with ðŸ“Š Compare All tab showing all bodies side-by-side, plus individual tabs for Governors (Art 153-162), Chief Ministers (Art 164), and State Council of Ministers (Art 163-164) with constitutional provisions, appointment, powers, and removal procedures

keyTakeaways: State Parliamentary system: Similar to Union - Governor nominal (constitutional head), CM real (head of government)
Governor (Art 153-162): Appointed by President (Art 155); Holds office during President's pleasure (removable anytime - Art 156); 5-year term; 35+ years, Indian citizen
Governor's dual role: Constitutional head of State + Centre's agent (controversial); Often acts politically; Sarkaria Commission recommended impartiality

Governor's powers: Appoints CM/Ministers (Art 164), Part of State Legislature, Assent to Bills (Art 200 - 4 options; Reservation for President Art 201), Pardoning (Art 161 - cannot pardon death sentence), Ordinance (Art 213), Recommends President's Rule (Art 356)
Governor's discretionary powers: Appointing CM (no clear majority), Dismissing govt (loses majority, refuses to resign), Reserving Bills for President, Recommending President's Rule - Often misused
Chief Minister (Art 164): Real executive head of State; Leader of majority in Assembly; Appointed by Governor; Must be member of Legislature (within 6 months)

CM removable by no-confidence in Assembly (Art 164(2) - collective responsibility); Powers - Similar to PM at State level (Appoints Ministers, Allocates portfolios, Advises Governor, Chairs Cabinet, Dissolves Assembly)
State Council of Ministers (Art 163-164): Headed by CM; Aids and advises Governor; Types - Cabinet, MoS, Deputy; Max 15% of Assembly (91st Amendment); Min 12 even if 15% < 12
Collective responsibility (Art 164(2)): All State Ministers collectively responsible to Assembly; No-confidence â†’ All resign; Individual responsibility for own Department

Governor vs President: Governor - No security of tenure (removable anytime), Cannot pardon death sentence, Often acts as Centre's agent; President - Impeachment only, Can pardon death sentence, Acts on Cabinet advice (bound by 44th Amendment)

subTopics.title: Central Government Funds (Art 266-267)
subTopics.description: Comparison table of Consolidated Fund of India (Art 266(1)), Public Account (Art 266(2)), and Contingency Fund (Art 267) with withdrawal procedures and parliamentary control

keyTakeaways: Parliament (Art 79) = President + Rajya Sabha + Lok Sabha. Bicameral legislature; LS more powerful than RS in all matters
Lok Sabha (543 members, 5-year term, directly elected by people - FPTP): Supreme legislative body; Controls Money Bills, Budget, no-confidence; Council of Ministers responsible ONLY to LS
Rajya Sabha (245 members, permanent body, 1/3rd retires every 2 years, elected by State Assemblies - STV): Represents federal character; Limited powers - can delay bills but not reject
LS vs RS: LS more powerful - Money Bills (Art 110), No-confidence (Art 75(3)), Budget & Grants; RS has exclusive powers - Art 249 (State List legislation), Art 312 (All India Services)
Money Bill (Art 110): ONLY in LS; RS can recommend (14 days, not binding); Cannot be returned by President; Speaker certifies (Art 110(3) - final)
Joint Sitting (Art 108): For Ordinary/Financial Bills (NOT Money Bills); President summons; LS Speaker presides; LS dominates (543 vs 245); Only 3 times in history
Question Hour (11 AM-12 PM): Most important accountability tool; Starred (oral + supplementary) vs Unstarred (written); NOT in Constitution (Rules of Procedure)
Zero Hour (12 PM-1 PM): Indian innovation (1962); NOT in Constitution/Rules; Members raise urgent matters without notice; No voting; Speaker's discretion
Motions: Adjournment (censures govt), No-confidence (Art 75(3) - only LS, 50 support, can topple govt), Censure (disapproval), Cut (Policy/Economy/Token during Demands)
Budget Process: Annual Financial Statement (Art 112) â†’ General Discussion â†’ Demands for Grants (Art 113) â†’ Appropriation Bill (Art 114) â†’ Finance Bill
Demands for Grants (Art 113): Voted ONLY by LS; LS can reduce/reject but NOT increase (Art 113(3)); Cut Motions used by opposition
Cut Motions: Policy Cut (Re 1 - disapprove policy), Economy Cut (specific amount - reduce expenditure), Token Cut (Rs 100 - discuss grievance)
Appropriation Bill (Art 114): Legal authorization to withdraw money from Consolidated Fund; Money Bill; Cannot be amended; Parliament's final control over expenditure
Consolidated Fund (Art 266(1)): All govt receipts & expenditure; Parliamentary Appropriation needed for withdrawal; Most important fund
Public Account (Art 266(2)): Govt as banker/trustee; Others' money (PF, small savings); No Parliamentary approval for withdrawal; Returned to rightful owners
Contingency Fund (Art 267): â‚¹500 crore; President's disposal; Emergency unforeseen expenditure; No prior Parliamentary approval; Post-facto reimbursement from CFI
Speaker (Art 93): Elected by LS; Final authority on Money Bill (Art 110(3)); Decides disqualification (10th Schedule); Casting vote only in tie
Chairman of RS: Vice President (ex-officio); NOT a member of RS; Casting vote in tie; Deputy Chairman elected by RS members
Quorum (Art 100(3)): 1/10th members (LS 55, RS 25); House adjourned if no quorum; Often misused to stall proceedings

Parliamentary Privileges (Art 105): Freedom of speech (can't be prosecuted for words in House); Immunity from civil proceedings during session; Art 122(1) bars courts from questioning validity of proceedings
connections: Parliament â†’ Union Executive: PM & Council responsible to LS (Art 75(3)); No-confidence only in LS; Budget must be passed by LS
Parliament â†’ President: President is part of Parliament (Art 79); Summons & prorogues Parliament (Art 85); Addresses Parliament (Art 87); Assent to bills (Art 111)
Parliament â†’ Federalism: RS represents States (federal character); Art 249 (RS allows Parliament to legislate on State List); Art 312 (RS creates All India Services)
Parliament â†’ Judiciary: Parliament can impeach President (Art 61), remove Judges (Art 124(4)), CAG (Art 148(1)); But cannot question judicial decisions (separation of powers)
Parliament â†’ Constitutional Amendments: Special majority needed (Art 368); Some amendments need 50% state ratification; Basic Structure cannot be amended (Kesavananda)
Budget â†’ Consolidated Fund: All expenditure from CFI needs Parliamentary Appropriation (Art 266(3)); Demands for Grants voted by LS (Art 113); Appropriation Act mandatory (Art 114)
Budget â†’ Executive Control: Parliament controls public purse; LS votes on Demands for Grants; If demands rejected, govt may fall; Cut Motions allow opposition to criticize
Money Bills â†’ LS Supremacy: Money Bills (Art 110) only in LS; RS limited to 14 days recommendation; Speaker's certificate final; President cannot return Money Bills

topics.description: Comprehensive side-by-side comparisons of legislative bodies at Union and State levels - Essential for understanding structural and functional differences

subTopics.title: Lok Sabha vs Rajya Sabha - Complete Comparison
subTopics.description: 40+ point comparison covering constitutional basis, composition, powers, procedures, and exam-relevant exceptional points

subTopics.title: Legislative Assembly vs Legislative Council
subTopics.description: 38+ point comparison of State legislative bodies covering powers, abolition procedures, bicameral states, and key distinctions

keyTakeaways: Lok Sabha MORE POWERFUL than Rajya Sabha: Exclusive control over Money Bills (Art 110), Budget, No-confidence (Art 75(3))
Rajya Sabha exclusive powers: Art 249 (State List legislation - 2/3rd), Art 312 (All India Services - 2/3rd)
LS (543 members, 5-year term, 25+ age, FPTP direct election) vs RS (245 members, 6-year term 1/3rd retire, 30+ age, STV indirect election)
Money Bill: Only LS originates; RS 14 days recommendation (not binding); Speaker certificate final (Art 110(3))
No-confidence: Only in LS (Art 75(3)); RS cannot remove govt; Council of Ministers responsible ONLY to LS
Joint Sitting (Art 108): LS dominates (543 vs 245); Only for Ordinary/Financial Bills (NOT Money Bills); Used 3 times only
Legislative Assembly SUPREME in State: Can abolish Council (Art 169); Exclusive budget control; CM responsible ONLY to Assembly
Legislative Council: Optional (only 6 States); Can be abolished by Parliament; 6 categories of members (1/3rd Local Bodies, 1/3rd Assembly, 1/12th Teachers, 1/12th Graduates, 1/6th Nominated)
Assembly (5-year term, 25+ age, directly elected) vs Council (6-year term 1/3rd retire, 30+ age, indirectly elected/nominated)
Council can delay Ordinary Bill 3-4 months, Money Bill 14 days; Cannot prevent Assembly from passing bills
Art 169: Assembly can abolish Council (Majority total + 2/3rd present) â†’ Parliament passes bill â†’ Council cannot prevent its own abolition
Only 6 States bicameral: AP, Telangana, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Bihar, UP; Others unicameral
Constitutional Amendments: Only Assembly ratifies (not Council) - Council completely excluded from ratification process

subTopics.description: Complete timeline: Art 40 DPSP (1950) â†’ Balwant Rai Mehta (1957) â†’ Ashok Mehta (1977) â†’ 64th Amendment failed (1989) â†’ 73rd Amendment (1992) â†’ PESA (1996)

keyTakeaways: 8 Union Territories: Delhi (NCT), Puducherry, J&K, Ladakh, Chandigarh, Andaman & Nicobar, Lakshadweep, DNH & DD
3 UTs with Legislature: Delhi (Art 239AA - 70 members), Puducherry (Art 239A - 33 members), J&K (114 members)
Delhi NCT: Art 239AA; 3 subjects reserved for Parliament (Police, Public Order, Land - Entry 1, 2, 18); 2021 Act strengthened LG
J&K: Only State downgraded to UT (2019); Art 370 abrogated; J&K Reorganisation Act 2019 - Most important for exams
Ladakh: Newest UT (2019); No Legislature; Demands 6th Schedule protection
5th Schedule (Art 244(1)): 10 States in central India; Scheduled Areas; Governor has special powers; TAC (max 20 members, 3/4th tribal MLAs); Land protection
6th Schedule (Art 244(2)): 4 North-East States (Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram); 10 ADCs with legislative, judicial, financial powers; Customary law protected
ADCs have MUCH greater autonomy than 5th Schedule TAC: Can make laws, levy taxes, constitute courts; 73rd Amendment NOT applicable to 6th Schedule
PESA Act 1996: Extended Panchayats to 5th Schedule areas; Gram Sabha SUPREME; Mandatory consultation on land, resources; Can prevent land alienation
73rd Amendment 1992: LANDMARK - Inserted Part IX (Art 243-243O) & 11th Schedule (29 subjects)
Mandatory provisions: 3-tier, direct elections, 5-year term, 1/3rd women, SC/ST reservation, State Election Commission, State Finance Commission, Gram Sabha
11th Schedule: 29 subjects (Agriculture, Education, Health, Minor irrigation, Drinking water, Roads, Poverty alleviation, Women & child development)
Effective April 24, 1993; 3 million elected representatives (1 million women); Largest democratic decentralization in world
Art 40 DPSP (1950): Non-justiciable directive; Balwant Rai Mehta (1957): 3-tier system; Rajasthan first (1959)

studyTips: Start with Constituent Assembly to understand how Constitution was formed - Dr. Ambedkar, Drafting Committee, 165 sittings
Memorize Preamble keywords - SOVEREIGN, SOCIALIST (42nd Amendment), SECULAR (42nd Amendment), DEMOCRATIC, REPUBLIC
Use Parts & Schedules table for quick reference - know which Part covers what (Part III FRs, Part IV DPSPs, Part V Union, etc.)
Use Split-Panel visual model to permanently retain concepts - master-detail interface allows quick navigation and deep content exploration
Article numbers are CRITICAL - Art 14, 19, 21, 32 for FRs; Art 37, 39, 44 for DPSPs; Art 34 (Martial Law), Art 358-359 (Emergency); Art 368 (Amendment); Art 1, 245-263 (Federalism)
Master 5 writs with Latin meanings - Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, Quo Warranto. Remember: Art 32 (SC) = FR itself; Art 226 (HC) = wider scope
Master FR vs DPSP comparison (25+ points): FRs justiciable/negative/individual vs DPSPs non-justiciable/positive/social. Use comparison table for quick revision
Learn FR-DPSP conflict resolution: Champakam (1951) FRs prevail â†’ Kesavananda (1973) Balance is basic structure â†’ Minerva Mills (1980) Two lungs theory
Constitutional Amendments: Know 3 types - (1) Simple majority, (2) Special majority, (3) Special majority + 50% states. 106 amendments till 2023
Amendment landmark cases: Shankari Prasad (unlimited) â†’ Golak Nath (FRs unamendable) â†’ Kesavananda (Basic Structure) â†’ Minerva Mills (Two lungs)
Basic Structure doctrine (Kesavananda 1973): Parliament can amend BUT cannot destroy basic features. 13-judge bench, 7:6 verdict. Most important case
Federalism: India is 'Quasi-federal' (K.C. Wheare) - Federal in structure (division of powers, dual polity) + Unitary in spirit (strong Centre, emergency)
7th Schedule crucial: Union List (97) - Defence, currency; State List (61) - Police, agriculture; Concurrent (47) - Criminal law, education. Residuary â†’ Union (Art 248)
Parliamentary System (Art 74, 75): Dual executive (President nominal, PM real), Collective responsibility to Lok Sabha (Art 75(3)), No-confidence can remove
Parliamentary vs Presidential: Know 25+ points comparison. India chose Parliamentary (Westminster model) - Familiarity, Accountability, Dr. Ambedkar's reasoning
Art 31C (25th Amendment): Laws implementing Art 39(b), (c) protected from Art 14, 19. 42nd Amendment extended to all DPSPs - Minerva Mills struck down extension
Property right battle: Originally FR (Art 19(1)(f), Art 31) â†’ 8+ amendments â†’ 44th Amendment 1978 removed as FR â†’ Now Art 300A (legal right). Biggest FR-DPSP conflict
Art 21 expansion: Maneka Gandhi (1978) revolutionized - Courts added livelihood, education, health, environment to Art 21. DPSP goals integrated into FRs
S.R. Bommai (1994): Federalism is basic structure. Parliamentary system is basic structure. Art 356 (President's Rule) abuse curtailed
Remember: Art 1 (India = Union of States, NOT Federation - states cannot secede). Dr. Ambedkar's explanation crucial
Practice comparison tables: FR vs DPSP (25+ points), Federal vs Unitary (20+ points), Parliamentary vs Presidential (25+ points)
7th Schedule crucial: Union List (97) - Defence, Currency, Railways; State List (61) - Police, Agriculture, Land; Concurrent (47) - Criminal law, Education. Residuary â†’ Union (Art 248)
Parliament in State field: Art 249 (RS 2/3, 1 year), Art 250 (Emergency), Art 252 (State consent, permanent), Art 253 (Treaty). All show strong Centre
President's Rule (Art 356): Most asked - S.R. Bommai (1994) case crucial. Federalism is basic structure. Floor test mandatory. 44th Amendment safeguards
Centre-State Executive: Art 73 vs Art 162; Art 256-257 (Directions); Art 355 (Union's duty); All India Services (IAS, IPS, IFS - dual control)
Finance: 14th FC (42%), 15th FC (41%) devolution. Art 275 (FC grants), Art 282 (Discretionary - CSS). Surcharges/cesses NOT shareable (controversy)
GST Council (Art 279A): Union 1/3 vote, States 2/3 vote. Best example of cooperative federalism. 101st Amendment 2016. Weighted majority 3/4
Remember numbers: Union List 97, State List 61 (originally 66), Concurrent 47. 42nd Amendment shifted 5 from State to Concurrent (centralization)
Vertical imbalance: Union has more revenue (Income tax, Customs, GST), States have more expenditure (Health, Education, Police) â†’ Depend on devolution, grants
Emergency Provisions: Three types - Art 352 (National), Art 356 (State/President's Rule), Art 360 (Financial). Use comparison table for quick revision
1975 Emergency: MOST ASKED - 21 months, democracy suspended, press censored. Led to 44th Amendment safeguards (special majority, Art 20-21 protected, LS disapproval)
44th Amendment Emergency safeguards: Special majority, Cabinet advice in writing, 'Armed rebellion' (not vague 'internal disturbance'), Art 20-21 CANNOT be suspended
S.R. Bommai (1994): CRITICAL for Art 356 - Federalism basic structure, justiciable, floor test mandatory. Reduced Art 356 misuse dramatically (125+ times used, mostly pre-1994)
Art 358 vs Art 359: Art 358 (Automatic - Art 19 suspended if war/external aggression), Art 359 (Presidential order - Other FRs, except Art 20-21)
Frequency: Art 352 (3 times - 1962, 1971, 1975), Art 356 (125+ times - most misused), Art 360 (0 times - never used)

Union Executive: Use TABS model with ðŸ“Š Compare All tab - Quick side-by-side comparison of all 4 bodies. President (Art 52-62), VP (Art 63-71), PM (Art 75), Council (Art 74-75). Dual executive - President nominal, PM real (Parliamentary system)
Parliament (Art 79-122): President + RS + LS. LS (543) > RS (245) in all matters. LS controls Money Bills (Art 110), Budget, No-confidence. RS can delay Ordinary Bills 6 months max
Money Bill vs Ordinary Bill: Money Bill (Art 110 only, only LS, 14 days RS, Speaker certifies, no return) vs Ordinary Bill (any non-financial, both Houses, 6 months delay, Joint Sitting)
Parliamentary Devices: Question Hour (11 AM-12 PM, most important), Zero Hour (Indian innovation, no rules), Motions (Adjournment, No-confidence, Censure, Cut), Quorum (Art 100(3) - 1/10th)

Budget Process: Art 112 (Budget) â†’ Art 113 (Demands for Grants - LS votes) â†’ Art 114 (Appropriation Bill - legal authority) â†’ Finance Bill (taxation). Cut Motions (Policy Re 1, Economy specific amount, Token Rs 100)
Funds: CFI (Art 266(1) - Parliamentary Appropriation), Public Account (Art 266(2) - No Parliamentary approval, trustee), Contingency Fund (Art 267 - â‚¹500 cr, President, emergency, post-facto)
President: Electoral College (MPs+MLAs) via STV; 5-year term; Impeachment Art 61 (violation of Constitution); Acts on Cabinet advice (Art 74 - 44th Amendment); Limited discretion

President's powers: Appoints (PM, Ministers, Judges, CAG, EC, Governors), Part of Parliament, Pardoning (Art 72 - wider than Governor), Ordinance (Art 123 - 6 weeks), Veto (3 types), Emergency (Art 352/356/360)
VP: Elected by MPs only (no MLAs); Ex-officio RS Chairman (Art 64); Acts as President (Art 65); Removable by RS resolution + LS agreement (simpler than impeachment)
PM: Real executive; Leader of majority in LS; Appointed by President; Removable by no-confidence (Art 75(3)); Powers - Appoints Ministers, Allocates portfolios, Advises President, Chairs Cabinet
Council of Ministers: Collective responsibility (Art 75(3)) - No-confidence â†’ All resign; 91st Amendment - Max 15% of LS; Types - Cabinet, MoS, Deputy; Cabinet = Inner core, real power

State Executive: ðŸ“Š Compare All tab shows all 3 bodies side-by-side. Similar to Union but at State level; Governor (Art 153-162), CM (Art 164), State Council (Art 163-164); Governor appointed by President, holds during pleasure (removable anytime)
Governor's dual role: Constitutional head + Centre's agent (controversial); Discretionary powers - Appointing CM, Dismissing govt, Reserving Bills, Recommending President's Rule (often misused)

Governor vs President: Governor - Removable anytime (no impeachment), Cannot pardon death sentence (Art 161), Often political; President - Impeachment only, Can pardon death (Art 72), Acts on advice (bound)
